com.hippikon.security
Interface Configurable

All Known Implementing Classes:
ConfigurableProtectedResource
public interface Configurable

The Configurable interface forms part of the extensibility mechanism of the authorization framework and should be implemented by fine grained objects or aggregave view helper objects where creating an empty class just to inherit ProtectedResource becomes unwieldy.

The need for the Configurable mechanism stemmed from a requirement to provide attribute and screen-section based security in a complex enterprise web application.

The getName() method should return the type name of the Configured protected object. This differs from ProtectedResource.getResourceName(), which returns the type of ProtectedResource.

An example of Configurable objects could be reports generated by a reporting engine (such as Crystal Reports) that need to be integrated into a JSP environment. The Report interface that wraps each generated report would implement Configurable and ProtectedResource. The getResourceName() method would return "Report" while getName() would return the unique name of a particular report, which would be used as protected-resource key in the policy-store XML configuration file.

Since:
JDK 1.2.2
Version:

Method Summary
 java.lang.String getName()
          Returns the name of a Configurable object.
 

Method Detail

getName

public java.lang.String getName()
Returns the name of a Configurable object. This will not be the class name or type of ProtectedResource, but some other unique identifier that is used by the framework to look up permissions in the PolicyStore..

Returns:
a unique identifier of a Configurable object instance
